Europeans stunned and challenged by new US security strategy
byline: By Philippe Ricard, Virginie Malingre (Brussels, Europe bureau), Allan Kaval (Rome (Italy), correspondent), Elsa Conesa (Berlin (Germany) correspondent), Cécile Ducourtieux (London (United Kingdom), correspondent), Jean-Baptiste Chastand (Vienna (Austria) correspondent) and Piotr Smolar (Washington (United States) correspondent)
subhed: In the document published on Friday, the Trump administration took the extraordinary step of weighing in on the domestic politics of its European allies. Across the EU and in London, reactions remain muted to avoid deepening an already growing rift.

title: A mere trickle of Gazans allowed to evacuate to Europe
byline: By Claire Gatinois, Allan Kaval (Rome (Italy) correspondent), Marine Leduc (Bucharest (Romania), correspondent) and Isabelle Piquer (Madrid (Spain) correspondent)
subhed: Despite the ceasefire signed in September, the evacuations of Gazans have remained restricted by Israel, while European countries have shown reluctance in their reception policies.

title: Inside a major investigation into tennis match fixing linked to gambling
byline: By Damien Leloup and Lucie Soullier
subhed: Three French tennis players were charged on October 18. They are suspected of having agreed to deliberately lose matches in exchange for money and of encouraging other players to do the same.

100 years of the photobooth: Meet the people keeping them alive
subhed: Created in New York in 1925, the analog photobooth has come close to extinction over the years. Two passionate restorers, Eddy Bourgeois and Virginie Voisneau, are helping keep the vintage booth alive in France and beyond.

title: Martin Parr, extraordinary photographer of the ordinary, dies at 73
subhed: Famed worldwide for his saturated images capturing leisure society, the British photographer died of cancer on Saturday at the age of 73.

title: The lawyer suing far-right French mayors for setting up Nativity scenes
byline: By Agathe Beaudouin (Nîmes (southern France), special correspondent)
subhed: French courts have repeatedly ruled that installing Nativity scenes in town halls is a breach of the 1905 law separating the churches and the state. Sophie Mazas works tirelessly to ensure the principle of 'laïcité' is enforced.
